comment: If you’re already familiar with binary search, I’d recommend the practice problem I introduced at 12:17.  It’s a nice problem from my business affiliate https://algoexpert.io/csdojo - from which you can get a discount with my referral code csdojo.

import java.util.Arrays;  public class Main {     public static void main(String[] args) {         int[] arrays= {95, 10, 11 , 13, 16, 17, 22, 32, 61, 92};         Arrays.sort(arrays);         System.out.println((binarySearch(arrays,61)));     }     public static int binarySearch(int[] arr, int target) {         int low = 0;         int high = arr.length -1;         while (low <= high) {             int mid = (high+low) / 2;             if (arr[mid] == target) {                 return mid;             } else if (arr[mid] > target) {                 high = mid - 1;             } else {                 low = mid + 1;             }         }         return -1;     }  }

# This is code for rotated array. First we define function for rotate array in particular direction then we give input that rotated array in Binary search code. # If the code will help you please like the comment. def rotate_ntime(arr,direction, n):     if direction=="Left":         for i in range(n):             left_rotate_one(arr)     if direction=="Right":         for i in range(n):             right_rotate_one(arr)      return arr  def left_rotate_one(arr):     temp=arr[0]     for i in range(len(arr)-1):         arr[i]=arr[i+1]     arr[len(arr)-1]=temp     return arr def right_rotate_one(arr):     temp=arr[len(arr)-1]     for i in range(len(arr)-1,0,-1):         arr[i]=arr[i-1]     arr[0]=temp     return arr  arr=[8,9,11,13,-2,3,4,7] arr=rotate_ntime(arr,"Left",4) print(arr)  def Binary_search(arr,target):     low=0     high=len(arr)-1     while low<=high:         mid = (low + high) // 2         if arr[mid]==target:             return mid         elif arr[mid]<target:             low=mid+1         else:             high=mid-1  print(Binary_search(arr,11))

I suppose you're talking about Time Complexity.  He broke down the number of steps an algorithm has to take when searching within 40 elements, showing how we get to the O(log N) aka logarithmic time complexity.  Since this algorithm halves an array until the element is found or halved's length is 1, that means the first halved array would be n/2, where n is the length of the array. If the element is not found, then n/4 if we use the main array's length, otherwise we could say n/2 of the halved array.  I don't think it's important to memorize this, but you should remember that whenever an algorithm keeps halving an array by looping or using recursion, then the time complexity should be O(log N). You can test that by doubling up the size of the input, and see the difference between the number of steps. As per its definition, O(log N) states that the number of steps grows by 1 when the input size is doubled.

I think there is a mistake with  last part of pointer movement when target = 12, when left pointer will be equal to right pointer, we will exit the while loop(Left = right) with return -1, left and right pointers will not pass over each other.
There is the mistake in "mid = ( left + right)/2", because this could lead to number overflow, when calculating "(left+right)". More precise statement is "mid = left + (right -left)/2".

please do u know how wan we solve the problem given at the end

The algorithm will work, but it will go through more iterations to find it. Let’s use 8 as the target. Using the example, the following steps occur:  - algorithm checks arr[3], target is greater than mid(7) so left pointer moves to 4 (target). - algorithm checks arr[5], target is less than mid(9) so right pointer moves to 4 (target). - algorithm checks (4 + 4) / 2, which gives a mid of 4 which returns our target.   Essentially if one pointer lands on the target it will keep searching by dragging the other pointer closer and closer until they’re both on target. The algorithm actually relies on this to find the target, only that if one pointer finds the target early on in the search it will take more iterations before the other target “catches up”.  You could include a check to see if either pointer is on the target if you wanted to, however given the relatively low number of steps even for large arrays, the provided example would work fine.  The algorithm also “technically” checks if the target is outside the array, it just does so indirectly. I guess it just avoids having to write ‘if’ statements for every edge case you want to check.  In a large array, the chance a random target lands on the element directly adjacent to your middle is pretty small. Overall if the algorithm runs faster for most cases then I’d be happy with that trade off.

class Solution { public:     int search(int A[], int n, int target) {         int lo=0,hi=n-1;         // find the index of the smallest value using binary search.         // Loop will terminate since mid < hi, and lo or hi will shrink by at least 1.         // Proof by contradiction that mid < hi: if mid==hi, then lo==hi and loop would have been terminated.         while(lo<hi){             int mid=(lo+hi)/2;             if(A[mid]>A[hi]) lo=mid+1;             else hi=mid;         }         // lo==hi is the index of the smallest value and also the number of places rotated.         int rot=lo;         lo=0;hi=n-1;         // The usual binary search and accounting for rotation.         while(lo<=hi){             int mid=(lo+hi)/2;             int realmid=(mid+rot)%n;             if(A[realmid]==target)return realmid;             if(A[realmid]<target)lo=mid+1;             else hi=mid-1;         }         return -1;     } }; last question solution

Hi, here is how I think:             First of all, we need to find how many elements have been shifted. We can do this by binary search the array and see which element is greater than the element next to it.   Then we can split the original array into 2 sorted arrays. We can check which array our target belongs to by comparing it with A[0]. (Actually, we can also check whether the entire array holds the target by comparing it to the element which is located in the split position.)    Finally, we can do another binary search for the chosen array.
he returns mid given the first if condition passes

He explained lol. Linear search is O(n) because you search in the entire array 1 by 1, but in average the target will be in the middle so you search half of the array in average O(n/2), where n is the amount of elements in the array.

The practice problem was fun!  public static int ShiftedBinarySearch(int[] array, int target){         int l=0, r=array.length-1, mid=0;               while(l<=r){             i++;             if(array[l]>array[r]){                 mid=(l+r)/2;                 if(array[mid]==target) return mid;                 else if(array[mid]<array[r]){                     if(target>array[mid] && target<=array[r]){                         l=mid+1;                     }                     else r=mid-1;                 }                 else{                     if(target>=array[l] && target<array[mid])  r=mid-1;                     else l=mid+1;                 }             }             else{                 mid=(l+r)/2;                 if(array[mid]==target){ return mid;}                 else if(target<array[mid]){ r=mid-1;}                 else l=mid+1;             }         }         return -1;     }

My idea for shifted binary search: Copy the array once, so that an array like [3,1,2] becomes [3,1,2,3,1,2]. Next, we compute the maximum and minimum values of our original array, which are 3 and 1, respectively. Then, we run 2 pointers to find the indices of the range between the minimum and maximum, which in our example the indices are 1 and 3, and we binary search through those values.

Binary search is usually used to introduce Divide and Conquer.  It's not wrong, but the way the method arr.index() is implemented probably using a linear searching (I'm guessing here). That means, if you don't have the element in the array you'd iterate through the array anyway.   In the Binary Search, first of all, the array has to be sorted, you "exploit" this property to make the algorithm work "faster". In this case, if the element isn't in the array in don't need to search for it, you just check the first and last element

def search(arr, target):     l = 0     r = len(arr)-1      while l <= r:         m = int((l + r) / 2)         if arr[m] == target:              return m         elif target > arr[r] and target < arr[m]:             r = m-1         else:             l = m+1     return -1 right?
